questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You work at a company named Contoso, Ltd.
Contoso has a Microsoft 365 subscription that is configured to use the DNS domains shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Contoso purchases a company named Fabrikam, Inc.
Contoso plans to add the following domains to the Microsoft 365 subscription:
✑ fabrikam.com
✑ east.fabrikam.com
✑ west.contoso.com
You need to ensure that the devices in the new domains can register by using Autodiscover.
How many domains should you verify, and what is the minimum number of enterpriseregistration DNS records you should add? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: The first question should be 1. Contoso is already verified and added, subdomains do not need verifying and adding so only fabrikam.com needs verifying. 3 CNAMEs are needed though for each domain.

The answer to the first part of the question is 1, not 3. 

"When you add a subdomain, it is automatically verified based on the parent domain that is being verified." - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/setup/domains-faq?view=o365-worldwide

It states "Contoso has a Microsoft 365 subscription that is configured to use the DNS domains shown in the following table" and therefore contoso.com has already been registered/configured. Therefore only root domain of fabrikam.com needs to be verified. The answer the first part of the question is 1.
minimum number of enterpriseregistration DNS records you should add is 1.
As contoso.com devices can already enrol, you have to make sure you can do the same for newly added Fabrikam.com . Now the question is asking about “enterpriseregistration DNS records” NOT EnterpriseEnrollement DNS records. There’s a difference between both. (refer to this link: https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/intune-customer-success/which-cnames-to-use-for-auto-discovery-during-mdm-enrollment/ba-p/279952 )
It needs one record per company_domain, as contoso is already added and can be enrolled, we need to add Fabrikam.

1 & 3
Add subdomains of a custom domain
If you want to add a subdomain name such as ‘europe.contoso.com’ to your organization, you should first add and verify the root domain, such as contoso.com. The subdomain is automatically verified by Azure AD.

3 Domains? 
If the company uses more than one UPN suffix, you need to create one CNAME for each domain name and point each one to EnterpriseEnrollment-s.manage.microsoft.com. For example, users at Contoso use the following formats as their email/UPN:

name@contoso.com
name@us.contoso.com
name@eu.contoso.com
Was in my exam today 05/08/22.

In the first box should be 3 (the answer is correct).
The domain needs to be always verified ! The verification is a simple DNS record to MSFT know that you are owner of the domain. The subdomains are automatically verified, but that not mean you bypass the domain verfication!
Seconde box is 3 also. All domains need a DNS record for registration device, even if its a sub domain.

Answer: 1, 3.

If the company uses more than one UPN suffix, you need to create one CNAME for each domain name and point each one to EnterpriseEnrollment-s.manage.microsoft.com. For example, users at Contoso use the following formats as their email/UPN:

name@contoso.com
name@us.contoso.com
name@eu.contoso.com

The Answer should be 1 domain - Fabrikam and 3 Enterprise Registration DNS which are CNames:
You need to ensure that the devices in the new domains can register by using Autodiscover.
Type Host name Points to TTL
CNAME EnterpriseEnrollment.fabrikam.com EnterpriseEnrollment-s.manage.microsoft.com 1 hour
CNAME EnterpriseEnrollment.east.fabrikam.com EnterpriseEnrollment-s.manage.microsoft.com 1 hour
CNAME EnterpriseEnrollment.west.contoso.com EnterpriseEnrollment-s.manage.microsoft.com 1 hour

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/enrollment/windows-enroll#step-1-create-cname-optional

The number of domains should be 1

"If you want to add a subdomain name such as ‘europe.contoso.com’ to your organization, you should first add and verify the root domain, such as contoso.com. The subdomain is automatically verified by Azure AD. To see that the subdomain you added is verified, refresh the domain list in the browser."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/domains-manage#:~:text=If%20you%20want%20to%20add%20a%20subdomain%20name%20such%20as%20%E2%80%98europe.contoso.com%E2%80%99%20to%20your%20organization%2C%20you%20should%20first%20add%20and%20verify%20the%20root%20domain%2C%20such%20as%20contoso.com.%20The%20subdomain%20is%20automatically%20verified%20by%20Azure%20AD.%20To%20see%20that%20the%20subdomain%20you%20added%20is%20verified%2C%20refresh%20the%20domain%20list%20in%20the%20browser.

Guys,

It's 1 domain: fabrikam.com (contoso.com already verified, and any sub-domain doesn't require verification)

Regarding the DNS Records the answer is 2: The autodiscover mentioned here is for enterprise registration , not Outlook Autodiscover. These are DNS records for mobile device management, which are 2 CNAME Records 
enterpriseregistration.domain.xxx point to enterpriseregistration.windows.net
and
enterpriseenrollment.domain.xx point to enterpriseenrollment.manage.microsoft.com
The second answer specifies EnterpriseRegistration DNS records not Autodiscover. So should answer bse 1 and 0? EnterpriseRegistration is used to redirect to intune so not for email.

1 domain
3 cnames

IMHO Answer 2 domains, 3 DNS records

Already in place an verified
• contoso.com
• contoso.onmicrosoft.com
New domains
• west.contoso.com verified from contoso.com
New adquisition Fabrikam
Need to be verified
• fabrikam.com
no needed to verify
east.fabrikam.com 
west.contoso.com 


When you add a subdomain, it is automatically verified based on the parent domain that is being verified.

We recommend that you create an Autodiscover CNAME record for every domain on your account, 
including domain aliases and accepted domains. 
You need to create either a CNAME or SRV record where your domain is hosted. 
Only then you can synchronize your offline address book, show free/busy information and enable the Out of office feature in Outlook.

• autodiscover.fabrikam.com 
• autodiscover.east.fabrikam.com 
• autodiscover.west.contoso.com

I agree with afbnfz. It states "Contoso has a Microsoft 365 subscription that is configured to use the DNS domains shown in the following table" and therefore contoso.com has already been registered/configured.

Therefore only root domain of fabrikam.com needs to be verified. The answer the first part of the question is 1 and 3 x CNAMEs

comments.content: Exactly my thought! you just need to verify contoso.com and fabrikam.com, but you'll need DNS for each subdomain.

discussion.content: You do not need to verify sub-domain and so you'll only need to verify fabrikam.com, for autodiscover though, each will need a CNAME.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a hybrid deployment of Microsoft 365.
Users authenticate by using pass-through authentication. Several Microsoft Azure AD Connect Authentication Agents are deployed.
You need to verify whether all the Authentication Agents are used for authentication.
What should you do?

comments.content: you can use a single server to collect the #PTA performance counters from several servers

In the Azure portal you only check the status of Agent: active or not, but not traffic. For this you need the performance counters.

"Pass-through Authentication provides high availability using multiple Authentication Agents, and not load balancing. Depending on your configuration, not all your Authentication Agents receive roughly equal number of requests. It is possible that a specific Authentication Agent receives no traffic at all."
And by A, I mean it's wrong because you're looking in the wrong place. You can check it in Azure Portal, is what I meant.

B requires you to check each server individually.
A allows you to check all at once. Azure Portal > Azure Active Directory > Azure AD Connect > click on Pass-through authentication. It will take you to the agents and give you their health.

discussion.content:
This should be B - the #PTA counter in Performance Monitor. Troubleshooting in Azure AD will only help if there is an active issue, the question states that you just wish to check that all agents are handling authentication requests.

Ref - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/tshoot-connect-pass-through-authentication#performance-monitor-counters

comments.content: A is right, see: https://docs.microsoft.com/nl-nl/azure/active-directory/hybrid/tshoot-connect-pass-through-authentication

discussion.content:
A is right 
It is asked to verifiy to "whether all the Authentication Agents are used for authentication"
so if the agent works fine and is seen with ACTIVE Status from the Azure portal then it can't be used for anything else : authentication. 
so the answer is A

Selected Answer: B
Took some time to set up but it 100% B.

Selected Answer: B
Confusing questions since both the performance-counters on each server as the "agents-page" in AzureAD-connect can be used to see what agents are "being used".
Depends if the question and answers on the exam will be exactly like this.
"On the troubleshoot page" should be something like "on the AAD-Connect blade".
Under "Agents" you can see what agents are active or inactive cause of on issue.
The "Troubleshoot" page one the AAD-Connect blade doesn't contain anything useful.
For that reason i'd go for B.

Selected Answer: A
Ensure that the Pass-through Authentication feature is still Enabled on your tenant and the status of Authentication Agents shows Active, and not Inactive.

A - MS WAY

Selected Answer: B
answer b PTA

IMHO
Answer B not right

Performance Monitor counters
Another way to monitor Authentication Agents is to track specific Performance Monitor counters on each server where the Authentication Agent is installed. Use the following Global counters (# PTA authentications, #PTA failed authentications and #PTA successful authentications) and Error counters (# PTA authentication errors):

Answer A Right
Check status of the feature and Authentication Agents
Ensure that the Pass-through Authentication feature is still Enabled on your tenant and the status of Authentication Agents shows Active, and not Inactive. You can check status by going to the Azure AD Connect blade on the Azure Active Directory admin center.

Reference
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/tshoot-connect-pass-through-authentication
Answer A is the right answer: https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs/blob/master/articles/active-directory/hybrid/tshoot-connect-pass-through-authentication.md
I think, this question could be rephrased in a different way.

I am hoping they give credit to either answer as technically both are correct. A and B but I think B is more correct because it goes into the whole being able to see which host is not being used as much reality as load balancing is not exactly a thing and/or if one host experiences issues that the others do not. A bit out of the scope for the question tho

comments.content:
No - A is definately not right....
There is absolutely nothing to see on the "Troubleshoot option" exept some links to help with different sync remidiations...
The place people here are referencing "seeing status etc" for each agent, is not in the "Troubleshoot" option.

Only correct answer is B...
also note the ALL in the question

discussion.content:
Agreed with B.
You were asked to verify whether Authentication Agents are USED.
Use #PTA counter 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/tshoot-connect-pass-through-authentication#performance-monitor-counters

Probably B is right.
They probably look for this answer with this question:
"Another way to monitor Authentication Agents is to track specific Performance Monitor counters on each server where the Authentication Agent is installed. Use the following Global counters (# PTA authentications, #PTA failed authentications and #PTA successful authentications) and Error counters (# PTA authentication errors)"

Ref - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/tshoot-connect-pass-through-authentication#performance-monitor-counters
B for sure!

Answer is definitely B ad d2an said. To monitor Authentication Agents is to track specific Performance Monitor counters on each server where the Authentication Agent is installed. Use the following Global counters (# PTA authentications, #PTA failed authentications and #PTA successful authentications) and Error counters (# PTA authentication errors):

Answer is wrong - (this answer is listed as correct on other websites too...)
On Azure Active Directory -> Azure AD Connect -> Pass-through authentication you can view the number of agents, authentication agent IP and status (e.g. Active)

This indicates that a PTA Agent is authenticated and connected to Azure Service. It does not mean that it is actually capable of authenticating users.

The question asks to verify whether Authentication Agents are USED for authentication.
That is done with #PTA authentications counter.

comments.content: Correct answer should be "B. From Performance Monitor, use the #PTA authentications counter."

You are overthinking this really! I know that MS can be peculiar about the wording of their questions. But, in my opinion, this is definitely about checking whether all the agents are functional - which is what you can do in Azure.

Also, I would be VERY surprised, if MS would reward knowlegde about the use of performance counters in current exams. They promote the shift to the cloud - and this is part of an older skill set which is not in focus anymore for them...

Agreed! If the question is asking to ensure "all the authentication agents are active" then it would have been A. But since the question is asking "all the authentication agents are used for authentication", you can ONLY verify this with #PTA counter.

choices.B: From Performance Monitor, use the #PTA authentications counter.
choices.C: From the Azure portal, use the Diagnostics settings on the Monitor blade.
choices.A: From the Azure portal, use the Troubleshoot option on the Pass-through authentication page.
choices.D: From Performance Monitor, use the Kerberos authentications counter.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription and a Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com.
Contoso.com is configured as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

You need to ensure that guest users can be created in the tenant.
Which setting should you modify?

choices.E: Deny invitations to the specified domains.
choices.D: Admins and users in the guest inviter role can invite.

discussion.content: D is correct

Selected Answer: D
It's D

questions.answer_description:
The setting ג€Admins and users in the guest inviter role can inviteג€ is set to No. This means that no one can create guest accounts because they cannot 'invite' guests. This setting needs to be changed to Yes to ensure that guest users can be created in the tenant.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/b2b/delegate-invitations https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/fundamentals/users-default-permissions

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com. The tenant contains the users shown in the following table.
//IMG//

From the Sign-ins blade of the Azure Active Directory admin center, for which users can User1 and User2 view the sign-ins? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Who can access the activity reports data?
✑ Users in the Security Administrator, Security Reader, Global Reader, and Report Reader roles
✑ Global Administrators
✑ Any user (non-admins) can access their own sign-ins
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/reports-monitoring/concept-sign-ins

discussion.content:
answer is correct :

Who can access it?
You can always access your own sign-ins history using this link: https://mysignins.microsoft.com

To access the sign-ins log, you need to be:

A global administrator

A user in one of the following roles:

Security administrator

Security reader

Global reader

Report reader

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/reports-monitoring/concept-sign-ins
Tested this and the answer is correct.

comments.content: Don't lie, you havent tested anything, because if you did, you would know that every single one of those roles can view sign ins for the other roles
Yes those users can but User2 is User admin, not one of these specific roles

Note: At this time, the special permissions, such as Deny, will not be saved.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepointmigration/understanding-permissions-when-migrating

discussion.content:
N, Y, N
1. No, because the file was created before 2019-03-01. Both conditions must be fulfilled.
2. Yes, both Created and Modified dates are OK.
3. No special permissions are preserved. "Deny" counts as a special permission.

The question is: How does the migration logic works? Does that mean that:

1: Files Create After some date AND Files Modified After other dates, or 
2: Files Create After some date OR Files Modified After other dates?

If option 1 is true, then answer 1 is NO as the AND statement will exclude it
If option 2 is true, then answer 1 is YES as the OR statement would be more inclusive

Filter is clear to me and everyone is calling for different answers but provide no documentation.
Should i read the filter as AND or OR?
This question was in my exam on 06/April/2022. I passed.

The Answer is : N, Y, N 
Please refer the link that says :
There are three types of permissions that will be migrated: Read, Write, and Full control.
Note: At this time, the special permissions, such as Deny, will not be saved.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepointmigration/understanding-permissions-when-migrating

comments.content:
The statement is:
"User1 will be denied access to read File3.txt in SharePoint when the migration is complete."

The answer is N because User1 will not be denied access. They will be able to access it.

Thank you for providing the link and explanation, but I'm confused by your conclusion for file3.
Domain users = read, User1=deny => special permission for user1 will not be migrated => user1 is domain user which means user1 can read the file!
So it must be Y

I can confirm as I just ran through everything in this question with my own tenant. Both conditions need to be met, and the Deny for User1 will be seen as a special permission and will ALLOW User1 to open the file in SPO.

Nice work, Kanag1!

discussion.content:
I think and based on the test that the answer is correct
The relation is AND, so
1 - No 
2- Yes
3- Yes, as the Domain users are granted access and will be migrated, but the deny wont be migrated. so the final result on the cloud will be that domain users can read and Domain users include User3
Correct me if I was wrong.
In exam today

deny is excluded from migration therefore 3. answer is yes
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepointmigration/understanding-permissions-when-migrating
1. answer from my side is yes too because it was modified inside the time frame... if it was not modified it would be no

Read the question again. We are talking about a "share". If you look at the exhibit, the "Preserve file share permissions" is set to on. That makes the answer YES.

NYY

I think N Y N...3rd answer Note: At this time, the special permissions, such as Deny, will not be saved.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepointmigration/understanding-permissions-when-migrating

YYY

On the first answer: 
I could still need a 20yo file, that would not be migrated if the implemented logic is AND.
Moreover, if the creation date field and the modify one use the logic operator AND only the file after March 2019 wil be migrated. 

So what's the point to set a creation date filter?

I think the answer is NYY

1. No, because the file was created before 2019-03-01.
2. Yes, both modified and created dates are OK.
3. Yes, the question says the user will be denied access, if the permissions are migrated over then they will be blocked from accessing the file.

People need to start using their heads. If all you need to do is modify a file to make it recent, then what's the point of the filters? Any super old file created 20 years ago can bypass this limitation, if all you need to do is make them have a new modified date. There's a reason for the filters and so both the created and modified date need to fulfill the condition.

i think should be y y y
there is no logic in it if the files must be created AND modified after a certain date.
If a file has been created in 1999 it does not mean it is no longer in use, that's what the modified after filter is for, to catch those files which are older already but still in use and therefor have to be migrated.

I think the file rights will be transfered as well:

Preserve user permissions for file share migration:- By default, this is set to On. If set to Off, no permissions will be preserved.
https://mundrisoft.com/tech-bytes/how-to-use-the-sharepoint-migration-tool/

VikingSWE you have it all right !!!
N, Y, N
1. No, because the file was created before 2019-03-01. Both conditions must be fulfilled.
2. Yes, both Created and Modified dates are OK.
3. No special permissions are preserved. "Deny" counts as a special permission.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepointmigration/understanding-permissions-when-migrating
Thanks for ;-)

comments.content:
When preparing for your file share migration, it's important to know what's being migrated when you use the SharePoint Migration Tool and what's not.

User level file and folder permissions Explicit deny permission will not be migrated

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepointmigration/fileshare-to-odsp-migration-guide

so 3 must be N

but there are two filtering rules.
1. when the file was created
2. when the file was modified.

file1 does not meet the first rule, but does the second. it should be migrated.
My thoughts exactly japhar
But it was modified after 1st march 19, so it should be a YES?
First answer is NO. File was created before 1st Jan 2019, and therefore doesn't meet the policy to be migrated to SharePoint Online.

discussion.content:
First answer should be yes because its modified after 1st march 19
There is no such Deny function on SharePoint online so third answer is no
The answer is correct, however, the 3rd answer is correct because user rights will be preserved, not because it will be migrated.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your network contains an on-premises Active Directory domain. The domain contains a server named Server1. Server1 has a share named Share1 that contains the files shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You have a hybrid deployment of Microsoft 365.
You create a Microsoft SharePoint site collection named Collection1.
You plan to migrate Share1 to a document library in Collection1.
You configure the SharePoint Migration Tool as shown in the exhibit.
//IMG//

For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
